title: How many symbols are there in Egyptian Hieroglyphs writing? - Quora

response.answer_text: Opinions vary, mostly because it’s not always easy to establish which hieroglyphs should be treated as separate entities rather than just variants on some standard form (just like whenever listing words in English it’s unclear whether you should treat “apples” as separate from “apple” or “thinks” as separate from “think”, only in the case of hieroglyphs there are even more factors to consider, such as the time period as well as the size). All in all, we end up with figures that tend to vary between one another by as much as a few hundred percent if not more. But just to give you something to go on, this pisspoorly edited Wikipedia entry on the Gardiner list of Hieroglyphs contains 730 hieroglyphs in each category, although in this case only the primary hieroglyphs are considered. To put it in perspective: I’ve just counted all the hieroglyphs that are listed within the JSesh* databank which includes both the main signs as well as all their possible derivatives and I’ve ended up with 7996. That’s seven thousand nine hundred and ninety-six Egyptian hieroglyphs and so I do believe that a general off-hand reply of “some eight thousand” would not be off point. That also gives us around eleven derivatives per “main” hieroglyph on average. These 7996 break down into the following categories: A — 841 B — 180 C — 591 D — 513 E — 468 F — 313 G — 459 H — 60 I — 219 J — 34 K — 38 L — 219 M — 362 N — 241 O — 538 P — 214 Q — 76 R — 233 S — 293 T — 240 U — 221 V — 186 W — 170 X — 32 Y — 39 Z — 55 Unclassified — 135 Ff. — 14 NU — 26 NL — 22 Tail Narrow Signs — 777 Low Broad Signs — 99 Low Narrow Signs — 88  So… just memorize some ten hieroglyphs on every single day for two years straight and boom, you’re good to go. Damn, learning long-extinct languages just couldn’t be any easier, now, could it? *A free tool for writing and arranging Egyptian hieroglyphs as well as easily one of the best text editors of any script that I’ve seen in a while—an absolute must-have for any amateur Egyptologist. And it’s ridiculously user-friendly, even a reanimated mummy would manage. You can find it here, although you may need to upgrade to the most recent version of Java but the setup wizard will redirect you to the proper website anyway.

It depends on how far back in time you want to go.   If one were to assume the base of Hieroglyphs discovered in archeological digs at Gerzeh in Ancient Kemet (predynastic Egypt) dating back to about 4010 BCE, we can postulate this to be the recovered inception of the Hieroglyphs we see today.    The predynastic base of Hieroglyphs has about 570 symbols that appear to by Hieroglyphs.  One can clearly see a similarity to early Sumerian Script / Cuneiform with about the same number of symbols.   More modern Hieroglyphs can be thought to have as many as 2900 symbols.  However it is debated if all the symbols are actual Hieroglyphs.
